DESCRIPTOR.STUDY_TITLE: Homo sapiens Transcriptome or Gene expression
DESCRIPTOR.STUDY_ABSTRACT: The differential expression profiles of lncRNAs and mRNAs were significantly different in HUMSC male germ-like cell differentiation. We identified one mRNA, ENST00000486554 that was crucial for HUMSC male germ-like cell differentiation. Our results could provide a systematic perspective on the potential functions of non-coding RNAs and provide novel insight into the complicated regulatory mechanisms of the differentiation of HUMSCs into male germ-like cells.

SAMPLE_ATTRIBUTE.VALUE: the Wharton's jelly tissue from individual umbilical cords

EXPERIMENT.TITLE: WGS of Campylobacter jejuni strain RM4279

DESIGN.DESIGN_DESCRIPTION: Libraries were prepared using the KAPA Low-Throughput Library Preparation Kit with Standard PCR Amplification Module (KAPA Biosystems) according to the manufacturers instructions except with the following slight modifications: 750 ng of DNA was sheared at 30 psi for 40 s and size selected to 700-770 bp following Illumina MiSeq protocols. PCR reaction was run with 3-5 cycles, using TruSeq LT and PCR primers (standard desalted, Integrated DNA Technologies; IDT) at final concentrations of 0.375 and 0.5 mM, respectively. Libraries were quantified using the KAPA Library Quantification Kit (KAPA Biosystems) and again with digital droplet PCR (ddPCR) on a QX200 system (Bio-Rad) using the Illumina TruSeq ddPCR Library Quantification Kit both using the manufacturers instructions except the ddPCR reaction had an additional 2 min annealing/extension time.

DESCRIPTOR.STUDY_TITLE: Campylobacter jejuni strains associated with different diarrheal outcomes
DESCRIPTOR.STUDY_ABSTRACT: Campylobacter jejuni is the leading cause of bacterial gastroenteritis in the world, and is associated with two different diarrheal outcomes in patients. These strains represent different known diarrheal outcomes in patients and in the neonatal piglet model, and were used for comparative genomics to better understand the pathogenesis of the different diarrheal outcomes of Campylobacter jejuni.

EXPERIMENT.TITLE: WGS of Campylobacter jejuni strain RM4275

DESIGN.DESIGN_DESCRIPTION: Libraries were prepared using the KAPA Low-Throughput Library Preparation Kit with Standard PCR Amplification Module (KAPA Biosystems) according to the manufacturers instructions except with the following slight modifications: 750 ng of DNA was sheared at 30 psi for 40 s and size selected to 700-770 bp following Illumina MiSeq protocols. PCR reaction was run with 3-5 cycles, using TruSeq LT and PCR primers (standard desalted, Integrated DNA Technologies; IDT) at final concentrations of 0.375 and 0.5 mM, respectively. Libraries were quantified using the KAPA Library Quantification Kit (KAPA Biosystems) and again with digital droplet PCR (ddPCR) on a QX200 system (Bio-Rad) using the Illumina TruSeq ddPCR Library Quantification Kit both using the manufacturers instructions except the ddPCR reaction had an additional 2 min annealing/extension time.

SUBMISSION.TITLE: Submitted by University Hospital Basel on 23-APR-2020

DESCRIPTOR.STUDY_TITLE: Agrobacterium species in bacteraemias, Switzerland, 2008 to 2019: a molecular epidemiological study
DESCRIPTOR.STUDY_ABSTRACT: Background: Agrobacterium spp. are infrequent agents of healthcare-associated outbreaks with bloodstream infections from a common point source. It is unclear, however, if outbreaks also occur on a national level. Our aim was to investigate potential Agrobacterium spp. clusters within Switzerland by whole genome sequencing.Methods: Nationwide descriptive study of cases in Switzerland, based on a prospective surveillance system (Swiss Centre for Antibiotic Resistance, anresis.ch), from 2008 to 2019. All patients with Agrobacterium spp. isolated from blood cultures were identified. A survey sent to the laboratories collected epidemiologic parameters of the patients, susceptibility testing, and additional cases. Whole genome sequencing (WGS) of the clinical isolates available was performed, and their relatedness investigated by SNP variant calling analysis.Results: We identified 36 cases of Agrobacterium spp. from blood samples. Besides one previously identified cluster, no further clusters at healthcare institution level were identified. WGS-based typing of 22 isolates showed no close clonal relationship between the cases besides the one previously established cluster.Conclusion and Relevance: Healthcare-associated Agrobacterium spp. bacteraemias from a point source may occur but seem to be an exception. There was no hint for an inter-institutional transmission. Multiple cases of invasive Agrobacterium spp. at one healthcare institution should prompt an outbreak investigation.
